passage_text: Salary Outlook. According to the BLS, the median annual salary for insurance agents was $48,210 in 2013. The best-paid 10 percent made more than $117,830, while the lowest-paid 10 percent made less than $26,030. The highest salaries were paid by securities and commodities firms, outpatient care centers and local governments. Insurance agents made an average salary of $63,610 in 2013, which is more than a sales representative ($54,410) and much more than a customer service representative ($30,870).

Salary Range. According to the BLS, 321,780 people worked as insurance agents nationwide as of May 2011. The average annual wage for these agents was $62,970, or $30.28 an hour. The top 25 percent could make $72,490 or more, with the top 10 percent reaching six-figure salaries of $115,300 or higher. Starting agents at agencies could make a salary in line with the 25th percentile, at $33,050, or the 10th, at $25,450. Insurance carriers ranked second, with 76,380 agents. They could make a salary in line with the 25th percentile, at $37,220, or 10th percentile, at $27,820.

Industry Breakdown. According to the BLS, the largest employer of insurance agents was insurance agencies, which employed 231,940 agents. Starting agents at agencies could make a salary in line with the 25th percentile, at $33,050, or the 10th, at $25,450. Insurance carriers ranked second, with 76,380 agents. They could make a salary in line with the 25th percentile, at $37,220, or 10th percentile, at $27,820.

Job Description for Insurance Agent. Sells insurance to new and current clients. May require an associate's degree with at least 2 years of experience in the field or in a related area. Familiar with standard concepts, practices, and procedures within a particular field. Our team of Certified Compensation Professionals has analyzed survey data collected from thousands of HR departments at companies of all sizes and industries to present this range of annual salaries for people with the job title Insurance Agent in the United States.

Average Insurance Agent Pay vs. Other Best Jobs. Insurance agents made an average salary of $63,610 in 2013, which is more than a sales representative ($54,410) and much more than a customer service representative ($30,870).

Salary. According to the BLS, the median annual salary for insurance agents was $48,210 in 2013. The best-paid 10 percent made more than $117,830, while the lowest-paid 10 percent made less than $26,030. The highest salaries were paid by securities and commodities firms, outpatient care centers and local governments.

Survey participants with less than five years' experience pocket $32K on average, but those with five to 10 years of experience enjoy a much bigger median of $37K. Insurance Sales Agents who work for 10 to 20 years in their occupation tend to earn about $39K. After two decades in the workforce, the average Insurance Sales Agent generally earns more than ever; median pay for this group is estimated at $45K.

Insurance Agent Salary. (United States). The average pay for an Insurance Agent is $36,337 per year. Skills that are associated with high pay for this job are Oral / Verbal Communication, Sales Management, Account Management, and Account Sales. $23,767 - $64,265

For example the median expected annual pay for a typical Insurance Agent in the United States is $46,728 so 50% of the people who perform the job of Insurance Agent in the United States are expected to make less than $46,728. Source: HR Reported data as of October 2015. Our team of Certified Compensation Professionals has analyzed survey data collected from thousands of HR departments at companies of all sizes and industries to present this range of annual salaries for people with the job title Insurance Agent in the United States.
